div.p: This paper is concerned with a real-time observerbased fault detection (FD) approach for a general type of nonlinear systems in the presence of external disturbances. To this end, in the first part of this paper, we deal with the definition and the design condition for an L ∞ /L 2 type of nonlinear observerbased FD systems. This analytical framework is fundamental for the development of real-time nonlinear FD systems with the aid of some well-established techniques. In the second part, we address the integrated design of the L ∞ /L 2 observer-based FD systems by applying Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy dynamic modeling technique as the solution tool. This fuzzy observer-based FD approach is developed via piecewise Lyapunov functions, and can be applied to the case that the premise variables of the FD system is nonsynchronous with the premise variables of the fuzzy model of the plant. In the end, a case study on the laboratory setup of three-tank system is given to show the efficiency of the proposed results. Index Terms-Fuzzy dynamic modeling technique, nonlinear observer-based residual generator, observer-based fault detection (FD), piecewise Lyapunov functions.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: S TRONGLY driven by the increasing demands for system reliability and safety, observer-based fault detection and isolation (FDI) and fault-tolerant control (FTC) technique have attracted considerable attention from both the academic and industrial communities over the past three decades [1]-[4].

Among involved studies, a framework of designing observerbased FDI systems for linear industrial processes has been well established [5]- [9]. Reviewing the recent publications on FDI studies reveals that nonlinear observer-based fault detection (FD) belongs definitely to the most challenging topics [10]- [13]. Significant research efforts have been devoted to some special types of nonlinear systems like switched systems [14], Lipschitz nonlinear systems [15], affine nonlinear systems [16], and networked control systems [17]. Generally speaking, a nonlinear observer-based FD system is composed of an observer-based residual generator, an evaluation function and a detection logic with a threshold [16]. Most of the research attention has been paid to the design approaches for nonlinear observer-based residual generators. In addition, it is of great significance to attain an early and real-time detection of potential faulty components or subsystems, since failure may result in disastrous consequences and hazards for personnel, plant, and environment. Therefore, the investigations on real-time FD approaches have attracted increasing attention from the engineering domains [18], [19].

Motivated by these arguments, the major objective of this paper is to address the analysis and integrated design issues of a real-time observer-based FD for a general type of nonlinear industrial processes with external disturbances. To be specific, in the first part of this paper, we study an L ∞ /L 2 type of observer-based FD systems to attain an early detection of potential faults. To gain a deeper insight into this nonlinear FD framework, the existence and design condition is investigated with the aid of input-to-output stability (IOS) [20] and weak detectablility concepts [21]. For a successful application of the results to the FD system design, a mathematical and systematic tool is needed in order to handle nonlinear issues.

On another active research frontier, over the past decades, the application of Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy-model-based analysis and synthesis technique to deal with nonlinear systems or even nonanalytic systems has received intensive attention from both research and application fields [22]- [24]. It has been demonstrated that by means of fuzzy dynamic modeling technique, the controller/filtering design issues for nonlinear systems can be conducted into solving a class of linear matrix inequalities in the Lyapunov-function-based framework [25]- [33]. Under such circumstances, FD problems have been studied in [34]- [37]. Nevertheless, most of these approaches have been lumped into searching a common positive definite Lypuanov function, which might not exist in some situations. This inherent conservatism has motivated the investigations on the fuzzy/piecewise Lypaunov-function-based approaches [38]- [41]. In fact, the fuzzy/piecewise Lyapunov functions are more general classes of Lyapunov function candidates than the common one and, therefore, can be applied to handle a larger set of T-S fuzzy systems. Moreover, it has been observed that the premise variables of fuzzy models for some complex industrial processes are usually partially or completely unmeasurable. Some works on the controller/filter design issues for fuzzy systems in presence of unmeasurable premise variables have been reported in [42]- [44]. However, to our best knowledge, the problems of designing FD approaches for such type of fuzzy systems via piecewise Lyapunov functions remain open, which drives this paper.

Encouraged by these observations, in the second part of this paper, we address the design issues of the aforementioned real-time observer-based FD problems for general nonlinear systems with the aid of fuzzy dynamic modeling technique. For this purpose, the nonlinear system is first described by a smooth "blending" of a set of T-S fuzzy models with normbounded approximation errors. Then an asynchronous fuzzy residual generator is developed via piecewise Lyapunov functions by handling the proposed design condition. Specifically, this asynchronous algorithm is able to deal with the situation that the premise variables of the residual generator are not the same as the premise variables of the T-S fuzzy models of the nonlinear plant. Based on the residual generator, an observer-based FD system is proposed with an embedded dynamic threshold. In comparison with the standard nonlinear L 2 observer-based FD approaches [16], [45], the proposed scheme may lead to a significant improvement on the realtime ability of the FD performance. A case study on laboratory setup of three-tank system is given in the end to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed FD scheme.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The needed preliminaries and problem formulation are stated in Section II. In Section III, an early and real-time observer-based FD approach is studied. Section IV is devoted to the study on piecewise fuzzy dynamic modeling and the integrated design scheme of fuzzy observer-based FD system for general nonlinear processes with disturbances. A case study is given in Section V to show the efficiency of the proposed results. The conclusions and future works are summarized in Section VI.

It is noted that L 2 -norm measures the "average energy level" of a signal over the time interval (0, τ ) and is suitable to measure the "size" of a slowly varying signal. In against, L ∞ -norm measures the (maximum) size of a signal at each time instant and therefore is often used to measure the size of a rapidly changing signal. In practice, both the energy level and the maximum absolute value are widely used for evaluating the residual signals. From application perspective, an early detection of faults could avoid/minimize disastrous consequences. To this end, L ∞ -norm is adopted for residual evaluation purpose in this paper, which plays an essential rule in realizing a real-time detection of faults that would cause an abrupt change in the residual signal.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: The major objective of this paper is to study the analysis and integrated design issues of a real-time L ∞ /L 2 type of observer-based FD systems for nonlinear processes with disturbances. To gain a deeper insight into this type of FD framework, the existence and design conditions have been discussed first. Then, a T-S fuzzy-model-based design scheme of this L ∞ /L 2 type of observer-based FD systems has been developed by solving the proposed design conditions via piecewise Lyapunov functions. In particular, this scheme can be applied to the case that the premise variables of the T-S fuzzy models of the plant are not measurable. This paper is strongly motivated by the increasing requirement on safety and reliability of complex industrial processes. The future works are dedicated to the investigations on: 1) the parameterization of observer-based FD systems for nonlinear processes in presence of disturbances and the application to the optimization of FD performance and 2) generalized H 2 observer-based FD systems.
